newsitem.title: Italy: Italian Senate to hold confidence votes on budget.
newsitem.headline: Italian Senate to hold confidence votes on budget.

text.p: Italy's centre-left government called three confidence votes in the Senate (upper house) on Friday to sweep aside some 3,000 opposition amendments blocking passage of the 1997 budget.

Civil service minister Franco Bassanini told the assembly the government felt constrained to call the votes after senators from the centre-right Freedom Alliance and separatist Northern League refused to withdraw the avalanche of amendments.
The votes will take place on Monday, parliamentary officials said.

Northern League members rose to their feet after the announcement and shook empty cans of plum tomatoes sold by the Cirio company. Prime Minister Romano Prodi faces possible indictment in a legal case related to the company.
Bassanini said the government was submitting three so-called umbrella amendments grouping all the articles of the budget bill and was putting them to confidence votes.
It was doing so "without any sense of satisfaction and without arrogance", he said.
Prodi has a comfortable majority in the Senate and his expected victory will strip away the blocking amendments.
The budget bill, designed to slash 62.5 trillion lire ($41 billion) from next year's deficit, is vital to Italy's hopes of joining Europe's planned single currency from the start in 1999.
Prodi's cabinet has said timely passage of the budget would be impossible if all the amendments had to be voted on.
Both houses must approve the budget by December 31. Costly provisional measures take effect if the deadline is missed.

"We cannot allow that now because we know it would be a sign of weakness and uncertainty of our will...to realise the objectives which are needed to join European monetary union from the start," Bassanini said.

The main opposition Freedom Alliance has been boycotting key votes on the budget in protest over a government request for special powers to legislate on some areas of policy, including fiscal reform, without recourse to parliament.
It has also organised street demonstrations against the package, which includes some 12.5 trillion lire of so-called "Euro-tax" measures to raise revenue.
Part of the "Euro-tax" is a one-off levy on income next year to help reduce the public deficit to the three percent of Gross Domestic Product required for countries aiming to join EMU.
